title-group.article-title: Preparation and properties of silicon-containing arylacetylene resin/benzoxazines blends

article-meta.aff: Key Laboratory for Specially Functional Polymeric Materials and Related Technology of the Ministry of Education, School of Materials Science and Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: Farong Huang, Key Laboratory for Specially Functional Polymeric Materials and Related Technology of the Ministry of Education, School of Materials Science and Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 399, 130 Meilong Road, Shanghai 200237, China. Email: fhuanglab@ecust.edu.cn

abstract.p: A series of aniline-based bifunctional benzoxazines (BZs) were synthesized using solventless or solvent method via the Mannich condensation reactions. The chemical structures of these BZs were confirmed using Fourier-transform infrared and proton-nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopies. The polymer blends were prepared by mixing silicon-containing arylacetylene (poly(dimethylsilyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene) (PSA)) resin with BZ in weight ratios at 110°C until a homogeneous viscosity liquid was obtained. The resultant blends were characterized by solubility tests, rheological analyses, differential scanning calorimetry, dynamic mechanical analyses and thermogravimetric analyses. The good solubility and low melt viscosity of the blends indicated excellent processability. The curing reactions resulted in the formation of interpenetrating polymer networks. The cured blends exhibited high glass transition temperatures (Tgs) and thermal stabilities. The compressive strength and flexural strength of the blend casts improved when compared with pristine PSA.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: High-temperature polymers were in great demand for high-speed aircraft structures and as structural components of space vehicles. There had been considerable interest in the silicon-containing polymers composed of a regular organosilicon and ethynylene units due to their high heat resistance. Itoh et al.1–3 found that poly[(phenylsilylene)-ethynylene-1,3-phenylene-ethynylene] [–Si(Ph)H–C≡C–C6H4–C≡C–] (named as MSP), which was prepared by the dehydrogenative-coupling polymerization reaction between phenylsilane and m-diethynylbenzene in the presence of magnesia, had an extremely high thermal stability. Td5 (the decomposition temperature at 5% weight loss) of cross-linked MSP was 860°C and the decomposition residue at 1000°C was 94% in an argon atmosphere. Buvat et al.4 synthesized poly(silyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene) terminated with phenylacetylene (named as BLJ) by condensation reaction between dichlorosilane and a mixture of diethynylbenzene and phenylacetylene magnesium reagents. The BLJ resin possessed good processability and high heat resistance (glass transition temperature (Tg) > 450°C, residue yield at 1000°C: 80%). In our previous study, poly(dimethylsilyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene) (PSA) was synthesized and showed high heat resistance and residue yield.5,6

Polybenzoxazine (poly-BZ), as a new type of phenolic resin developed recently, had many fascinating characteristics such as excellent thermal stability, good mechanical properties, low water absorption, low dielectric constant and near-zero shrinkage upon curing.7–9 They were prepared by the ring-opening polymerization of the corresponding BZs without any catalyst (Figure 1).10 BZs could be prepared from inexpensive raw materials including phenols, primary amines and formaldehydes. The various raw materials afforded considerable molecular design flexibility for BZs.11–19

caption.p: Thermal ring-opening polymerization of a benzoxazine.

sec.p: The disadvantages of silicon-containing arylacetylene polymers were their brittleness, high cost, low thermo-oxidative stability and poor mechanical properties, which restricted their applications. Some attempts had been made in order to improve the properties of PSA and to expand their application scopes. An effective approach for the performance improvement was the synthesis of novel structures containing additional groups.20–22 Other strategies for performance improvement of PSA were the preparation of copolymers23,24 and polymer blends. In this study, a series of aniline-based bifunctional BZs were blended with PSA to form polymer blends, aiming to enhance the mechanical properties of PSA with less sacrificing thermal stability. The rheological properties, curing behavior, thermal and mechanical properties of the blends were investigated.

sec.title: Raw chemicals
sec.p: All chemicals were commercially available compounds and were used as received without further purification. Bifunctional BZs were synthesized using aniline, formaldehyde and phenols: bisphenol-A (4,4′-isopropylidene diphenol; Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, Shanghai, China), bisphenol-AF (4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)diphenol, Shanghai Yichao Chemical Co., Ltd, Shanghai, China), 4,4′-oxydiphenol (Wuxi Sheng’an Chemical Co., Ltd, Wuxi, China), 4,4′-thiodiphenol (Zhejiang Shou & Fu Chemical Co., Ltd, Zhejiang, China), 4,4′-dihydroxybenzophenone (Henan Hengyu Solvent Co., Ltd, Zhengzhou, China), 4,4′-biphenol (Shanghai Bangcheng Chemical Co., Ltd, Shanghai, China) and bisphenol-S (4,4′-dihydroxydiphenyl sulfone, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, Shanghai, China). Other reagents were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). PSA was prepared in our lab.5,6

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: Infrared spectroscopic measurements were performed in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 at a resolution of 1.0 cm−1 on a Nicolet Avatar 5700 (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA) Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectrophotometer. Proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra were recorded in deuterated chloroform with tetramethylsilane as an internal standard, using a Bruker Avance 400 (Bruker Corporation, USA) instrument. The rheological behaviors were measured using a Thermo Hakke RS600 (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA) rotational rheometer operated at a heating rate of 2°C/min and a shear rate of 0.01s−1. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were carried out with an NETZSCH STA 409 PC/PG (NETZSCH-Gerätebau GmbH, Germany) instrument at a scanning rate of 10°C/min under nitrogen (N2) flow (20 mL/min). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a SDT Q600 (TA Instruments, USA) Thermogravimetric Analyzer operated at a heating rate of 10°C/min from room temperature to 1000°C under a continuous flow of N2 of 50 mL/min. Dynamic mechanical analyses (DMAs) were conducted on a Q800 DMA (TA Instruments, USA) at a frequency of 1 Hz and a heating rate of 5°C/min. Specimens with dimensions of 50 mm × 14 mm × 4 mm were tested in a three-point bending mode. The compressive properties of the resin casts were determined using a Universal Testing Machine CMT4204 (Shenzhen SANS Test Machine Co., Ltd, Shenzhen, China), according to China Standard GB/T 2569-1995 at a rate of 5 mm/min. Circular cylinder-shaped samples of 10 mm diameter and 25 mm height were used for compressive tests. Flexural measurements were carried out with a Universal Testing Machine CMT4204 according to China Standard GB/T 2570-1997 at a crosshead rate of 2 mm/min. Specimens with dimensions of 80 mm × 15 mm × 4 mm were tested in a three-point loading mode. Measurements were taken using five samples. The data presented were an average of five samples.

BZs based on bisphenol-A, bisphenol-AF, 4,4′-oxydiphenol and 4,4′-thiodiphenol were separately synthesized in a solventless system and purified according to the reported method (Figure 2).25,26 BZs based on 4,4′-dihydroxybenzophenone, 4,4′-biphenol and bisphenol-S were prepared in 1,4-dioxane (Figure 3).10 The abbreviation for BZs names are shown in Figures 2 and 3.

caption.p: Synthesis of BA-a, BAF-a, BO-a and TP-a in a solventless system. BA-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)isopropane; BAF-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)hexafluoropropane; BO-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)ether; TP-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)thioether.

Synthesis of BZ-a, BP-a and BS-a in 1,4-dioxane. BZ-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)ketone; BP-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)biphenyl; BS-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)sulfone.

sec.title: BA-a
sec.p: mp: 70°C. Yield: 78%. FTIR (potassium bromide (KBr), cm−1): 1496 (1,2,4-trisubstituted benzene ring), 1228 (asymmetric stretching of C–O–C), 1162 (asymmetric stretching of C–N–C), 942 (out of plane bending vibrations of C–H). 1H NMR (deuterated chloroform (CDCl3), ppm) δ: 1.57 (s, 6H, CH3), 4.56 (s, 2H, C–CH2–N–), 5.30 (s, 2H, N–CH2–O–), 6.67–7.25 (m, 16H, aromatics).

sec.title: BAF-a
sec.p: mp: 86°C. Yield: 75%. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 1500 (1,2,4-trisubstituted benzene ring), 1244 (asymmetric stretching of C–O–C), 1129 (asymmetric stretching of C–N–C), 935 (out of plane bending vibrations of C–H). 1H NMR (CDCl3, ppm) δ: 4.59 (s, 2H, C–CH2–N–), 5.36 (s, 2H, N–CH2–O–), 6.74–7.28 (m, 16H, aromatics).

sec.title: BO-a
sec.p: mp: 73°C. Yield: 77%. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 1489 (1,2,4-trisubstituted benzene ring), 1220 (asymmetric stretching of C–O–C), 1170 (asymmetric stretching of C–N–C), 937 (out of plane bending vibrations of C–H). 1H NMR (CDCl3, ppm) δ: 4.52 (s, 2H, C–CH2–N–), 5.29 (s, 2H, N–CH2–O–), 6.59–7.25 (m, 16H, aromatics).

sec.title: TP-a
sec.p: mp: 68°C. Yield: 73%. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 1485 (1,2,4-trisubstituted benzene ring), 1230 (asymmetric stretching of C–O–C), 1158 (asymmetric stretching of C–N–C), 938 (out of plane bending vibrations of C–H). 1H NMR (CDCl3, ppm) δ: 4.53 (s, 2H, C–CH2–N–), 5.31 (s, 2H, N–CH2–O–), 6.70–7.25 (m, 16H, aromatics).

sec.title: BZ-a
sec.p: mp: 108°C. Yield: 59%. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 1495 (1,2,4-trisubstituted benzene ring), 1231 (asymmetric stretching of C–O–C), 1144 (asymmetric stretching of C–N–C), 928 (out of plane bending vibrations of C–H). 1H NMR (CDCl3, ppm) δ: 4.66 (s, 2H, C–CH2–N–), 5.42 (s, 2H, N–CH2–O–), 6.81–7.54 (m, 16H, aromatics).

sec.title: BP-a
sec.p: mp: 96°C. Yield: 55%. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 1496 (1,2,4-trisubstituted benzene ring), 1231 (asymmetric stretching of C–O–C), 1144 (asymmetric stretching of C–N–C), 938 (out of plane bending vibrations of C–H). 1H NMR (CDCl3, ppm) δ: 4.65 (s, 2H, C–CH2–N–), 5.37 (s, 2H, N–CH2–O–), 6.81–7.29 (m, 16H, aromatics).

sec.title: BS-a
sec.p: mp: 90°C. Yield: 50%. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 1497 (1,2,4-trisubstituted benzene ring), 1237 (asymmetric stretching of C–O–C), 1144 (asymmetric stretching of C–N–C), 922 (out of plane bending vibrations of C–H). 1H NMR (CDCl3, ppm) δ: 4.62 (s, 2H, C–CH2–N–), 5.36 (s, 2H, N–CH2–O–), 6.82–7.64 (m, 16H, aromatics).

sec.title: Preparation of PSA/BZ blends and their casts
sec.p: PSA was blended with BZs in weight ratios. The weighed amounts of PSA and BZs were mixed in a three-necked flask equipped with a mechanical stirrer and a condenser. The mixtures were heated to 110°C with stirring until a homogeneous viscosity liquid was obtained. The blend casts were prepared at elevated temperatures by pouring the blends obtained above into a mold. The mold with the blends was placed into a vacuum oven at 130°C for 1–2 h and then removed into another oven under air. The blends were subjected to curing in a stepwise manner. The curing was carried out at 150°C for 2 h, 170°C for 2 h, 210°C for 2 h and 250°C for 4 h.

sec.title: Rheological properties of PSA/BZ blends
sec.p: The viscosity response of PSA/BZ (70:30) blends to temperatures at a heating rate of 2°C/min and a shear rate of 0.01s−1 was shown in Figure 4. As shown in Figure 4, the viscosity of the blends was below 4.0 Pa s at the temperature above 90°C, then kept constant and increased dramatically with the increase in temperature due to the curing reaction of the blends. As the temperature increased, the blends were melted, and the liquid state was maintained at constant viscosity, and finally the gelation of the blends occurred. The processing temperatures (the range of temperature in which the viscosity of the blends remained at low level or flow state) and gel temperature of the blends were shown in Figure 4 and Table 1, respectively. PSA/BAF-a had the narrowest processing temperature range, whereas PSA/TP-a and PSA/BS-a had the widest processing temperature range. Therefore, the blends possessed good processability.

caption.p: Viscosity–temperature curves of PSA/benzoxazine (70:30) blends. PSA: poly(dimethylsilyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene).

fn.p: PSA: poly(dimethylsilyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene); BA-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)isopropane; BAF-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)hexafluoropropane; BO-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)ether; TP-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)thioether; BZ-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)ketone; BP-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)biphenyl; BS-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)sulfone.

sec.p: In addition, the blends exhibited good solubility in toluene, acetone, ethyl acetate, tetrahydrofuran, ethyl ether, chloroform, etc., at room temperature, which indicated their good solution processability.

sec.title: Curing behavior of PSA/BZ blends
sec.p: The curing behavior of PSA/BA-a was examined by DSC. Figure 5 showed the DSC thermograms of PSA/BA-a blends with various ratios, and the results were listed in Table 2. There were two kinds of reactions of the blends when the temperature rose. BZs would undergo thermal ring-opening polymerization to form the corresponding poly-BZs without any catalyst.10 The polymerization of carbon–carbon triple bonds in PSA would take place to form conjugated polyenes, benzene rings, naphthalene rings, etc.27–29 As shown in Figure 5, the DSC diagram of PSA showed an exothermic peak with onset at 220°C and maximum at 241°C due to the polymerization of carbon–carbon triple bonds, whereas BA-a with onset at 208°C and maximum at 234°C corresponding to the ring-opening polymerization. As for PSA/BA-a blends, the exothermic peaks shifted to a higher temperature range with the increase in BA-a content. Besides, PSA/BA-a showed a broader exothermic peak and increased exothermic amount, which might be attributed to the multiple and complicated curing reactions of the blends, and the exotherm of oxazine ring-opening polymerization highly overlapped with the exotherm of the polymerization of carbon–carbon triple bonds in a wide temperature range.30

caption.p: DSC curves of PSA/BA-a blends with various ratios. PSA: poly(dimethylsilyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene); DSC: differential scanning calorimetry; BA-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)isopropane.
DSC analysis results of PSA/BA-a blends with various ratios.

fn.p: PSA: poly(dimethylsilyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene); DSC: differential scanning calorimetry; BA-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)isopropane; Ti: initial curing temperature; Tp: peak curing temperature; Tf: final curing temperature.

sec.p: The curing behavior of PSA/BA-a (70:30) was also monitored by FTIR spectra after each cure stage as shown in Figure 6. The characteristic absorptions at 3291 and 2153 cm−1 were assigned to the ≡C–H and C≡C stretching mode, respectively. The characteristic absorptions at 1232 and 1030 cm−1 were due to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching of C–O–C of BZ ring, respectively. These characteristic absorptions simultaneously decreased upon the polymerization. Meanwhile, a new band at 3300–3500 cm−1 assigned to the stretching of OH group appeared through oxazine ring-opening polymerization. These results indicated that the polymerization of BZ and carbon–carbon triple bonds occurred simultaneously. However, the peak at 2153 cm−1 did not vanish completely at the end of 250°C stage which was attributed to the residue internal ethynylene groups as evidenced by FTIR.

caption.p: FTIR spectra of PSA/BA-a at the end of each cure stage (cure stages: 150°C/2 h + 170°C/2 h + 210°C/2 h + 250°C/4 h). FTIR: Fourier-transform infrared; PSA: poly(dimethylsilyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene); BA-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)isopropane.

sec.p: A single exotherm in the DSC and simultaneously decreased characteristic absorptions in the FTIR indicated simultaneously forming interpenetrating polymer networks (IPNs).

The DSC curves of different PSA/BZ (70:30) blends were shown in Figure 7 and the DSC analysis results were summarized in Table 3. As shown in Figure 7, all the DSC curves of PSA/BZ blends showed single but broader exothermic peaks. This phenomenon could possibly be attributed to the steric hindrance effect of the forming of IPNs during polymerization. The peak temperatures for all the blends were close to 250°C. This illustrated the structures of BZ did not influence the curing reaction too much.

caption.p: DSC curves of PSA/benzoxazine (70:30) blends. PSA: poly(dimethylsilyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene); DSC: differential scanning calorimetry.
DSC analysis results of PSA/benzoxazine (70:30) blends.

fn.p: PSA: poly(dimethylsilyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene); DSC: differential scanning calorimetry; BA-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)isopropane; BAF-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)hexafluoropropane; BO-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)ether; TP-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)thioether; BZ-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)ketone; BP-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)biphenyl; BS-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)sulfone; Ti: initial curing temperature; Tp: peak curing temperature; Tf: final curing temperature.

sec.title: Viscoelastic properties of cured PSA/BZ blends
sec.p: The viscoelastic properties of cured PSA/BZ were investigated using DMAs. Figure 8 showed the temperature dependence of the storage modulus, loss modulus and tan δ for cured PSA/BA-a blends with various ratios. The cured PSA showed a high storage modulus (E′) of 3.3 GPa at room temperature. The spectra of loss modulus (E′) and tan δ did not show Tg from room temperature to 500°C. But loss modulus (E′) showed broad sub-Tg transition from room temperature to 300°C. The E′ spectrum in the glassy region showed minor drop and recovery at about 320°C with increase in temperature due to further cross-linking reactions of residue internal ethynylene groups.31 That is to say the polymerization of residual internal ethynylene groups at higher temperature (above 300°C) contributed the change in the storage modulus.

caption.p: Dynamic mechanical spectra of cured PSA/BA-a with various ratios: 100:0 (a), 90:10 (b), 70:30 (c), 50:50 (d) and 30:70 (e). PSA: poly(dimethylsilyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene); BA-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)isopropane.

sec.p: The same tendency could be seen from E′ and E′ of cured PSA/BA-a blends with lower BA-a content (Figure 8(b) and (c)). Owing to the high cross-linking density and chain entanglements of the IPN structures, the molecular segments motion was restricted, thus resulting in extremely high Tgs. With further increase in BA-a content, the Tg of poly-BZ appeared. The Tg of cured PSA/BA-a (50:50) and PSA/BA-a (70:30) were 336°C and 240°C, respectively, as determined by the maximum of tan δ. The Tgs were attributed to the poly-BZ segments motion and were much higher than that of pristine BA-a reported (171°C).11,13 This result illustrated that the cross-linked networks of PSA greatly restricted the segmental mobility of poly-BZ and the formation of IPNs in the PSA/BA-a system.

sec.title: Mechanical properties of cured PSA/BZ blends
sec.p: The compressive and flexural properties of PSA/BA-a (70:30) casts compared with pristine PSA casts were listed in Table 4. As shown in Table 4, the mechanical properties of the blends were improved. The results of the mechanical properties indicated enhanced toughness. The improvement was mainly attributed to the polarity of poly-BZ, suggesting that adding BZ to PSA was effective for performance enhancement to some extent.

sec.title: Thermal stability of cured PSA/BZ blends
sec.p: The thermal stability of cured PSA/BA-a with various ratios was investigated by TGA. The TGA curves in N2 were shown in Figure 9 and the decomposition temperatures at 5 and 10% weight loss (Td5 and Td10) and the residue yield at 800°C were listed in Table 5. The Td5, Td10 and residue yield at 800°C were dramatically decreased with the increase in BA-a content. As shown in Table 5, the blends with certain content of BZ (e.g. PSA/BA-a (90:10)) exhibited good thermal stability.

caption.p: TGA curves of cured PSA/BA-a with various ratios: 100:0 (a), 90:10 (b), 70:30 (c), 50:50 (d), 30:70 (e) and 0:100 (f). PSA: poly(dimethylsilyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene); TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; BA-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)isopropane.
TGA results of cured PSA/BA-a at various ratios.

sec.p: The TGA curves of different cured PSA/BZ (70:30) blends in N2 were shown in Figure 10, and the results were summarized in Table 6. The residue yields at 800°C were from 82% to 86%, and the temperatures at 5% weight loss (Td5) were in the range of 492–536°C. The cured blends showed excellent thermal stability. As shown in Figure 10 and Table 6, the residue yields of cured PSA/BZ blends were not significantly affected by the various phenol linkages under N2. Based on the temperatures at 5% weight loss (Td5), the trend of stability was as follows: PSA/BP-a < PSA/BS-a < PSA/BA-a < PSA/BAF-a < PSA/BO-a < PSA/TP-a < PSA/BZ-a. The similar trend of thermal stability of poly-BZ was previously reported.32 As shown in Table 6, the high Td5 and char yield were achieved for poly-BZs containing thermally stable linking moieties such as thio, ether, ketone and fluorine-containing group.

caption.p: TGA curves of cured PSA/benzoxazine (70:30) blends. PSA: poly(dimethylsilyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene); TGA: thermogravimetric analysis.
TGA results of cured PSA/benzoxazine (70:30) blends.

fn.p: PSA: poly(dimethylsilyleneethynylenephenyleneethynylene); TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; BA-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)isopropane; BAF-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)hexafluoropropane; BO-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)ether; TP-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)thioether; BZ-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)ketone; BP-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)biphenyl; BS-a: bis(3-phenyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,3-benzoxazinyl)sulfone.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A series of aniline-based bifunctional BZs were successfully synthesized via a Mannich condensation approach, and the structures had been confirmed by FTIR and 1H NMR spectroscopies. The rheological properties, curing behavior, thermal and viscoelastic properties of the blends prepared by melt blending of BZs with PSA resin were investigated. DSC curves showed single exothermic peaks. The thermal-induced polymerizations of the blends involved the ring-opening polymerization of BZ and the simultaneous polymerization of PSA to afford the IPNs. The cured blends showed high Tg and thermal stability. The temperature at 5% weight loss was in the range of 492–536°C and the residue yield at 800°C was in the range of 82–86%. The mechanical properties of the cured blends were improved when compared with that of pristine PSA. The structures of BZs mainly influenced the thermal properties of the blends to some extent.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
